## Software Misc
[@christianbundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519)  [posted](%33duDpTudjd5MOQ217ZMmQ98rUHSJWsYLy2sNdTt9X0=.sha256)

> Just in case anyone else has wondered what posts would look like with more of a Reddit or "Hacker" "News" style: it's not great.

![patchbay forum bulletin board](&kNIWX3JRL9VB9ncIPEL2XGRUSzQ8ALjf7zg/CB689mI=.sha256)

----
[@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) [asked some questions about Privacy and Security on SSB](%CEqN/Gqsow2ovZ8UdA4w0J5/rRpMOdH80R9GiH4Lcvc=.sha256) and got some useful answers (good for new folks). 

## Community
[@bobhugen](@iL6NzQoOLFP18pCpprkbY80DMtiG4JFFtVSVUaoGsOQ=.ed25519) was [discussing a local emergency situation](%HL52KycuiLQOMTBdf+Sm29/PWSj25xa4PdcufNlGzM8=.sha256) where information was dispersed via Facebook. SSB is obviously great in disaster scenarios but how do we overcome the network effect and/or expectation that FB is where you go to find out community news?

----

[@andresaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) asked 

> [What was your first internet community experience?](%ZwXw8U5f1v5y57X3qhw4JbzyYPI9NYyT/kd9/nBuYDs=.sha256)

and people answered.

----
[@mijkl](@70mCOxEUBDup8sP1ec7XjCQqJmN6/XQDVf7wRKyjEvQ=.ed25519) describes [how discovering SSB led them to a job working on Holochain full time](%d5o+/c4NPMoO2YSg2YWWcOKfn0iYeymWDSx5Tqk5eNg=.sha256).


---
[@Alana](@6OxffMLNyxkboLjCqv29WnMPhH8O3qFrcXCR6KrKcPI=.ed25519) 

> [Has] joined a kind of online anti-racism fire fighting crew, who gets into comment threads that have or likely will go toxic and tries to change the tide.

The "Terms of Engagement" [are worth a read](%akyJPBUD1YyDVYTVsLRSQr/Xu/bqx4vr3rZM6yMzu7w=.sha256) for anyone considering similar work.

-----
[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) started [discussing the idea of LiquidTrust](%QAHmdokXqjeBI1weQYX8qXRlxM6V020gbx8h+QQ0XkI=.sha256)

> "LiquidTrust" is a trust model somewhere in between trust than "trustless"... In a liquid trust system, you need to give someone your trust, but you can choose who. You can also revoke your trust in specific actors, but the system will continue to function for you...Really, we've been thinking about this idea the whole time we've been working on ssb, but we've lacked a catchy name for it...

And [@elavoie](%ifBuzRm8OhexBUypd/torps2taVYM+WF/5Ab9mZzMwE=.sha256) followed it with [a discussion of Liquid Association](%ifBuzRm8OhexBUypd/torps2taVYM+WF/5Ab9mZzMwE=.sha256) 

> Summary: We don‚Äôt need presidents, secretaries, or core contributors to organize in groups around common issues and interests. Voluntary groups may instead form and evolve by individuals with equal power greeting/shunning one another to form emergent sub-groups, and then leaving once their interest in the issue or in the group dynamics has waned.

----

[@randolo](@aQV1aq8xTp4AZ7m8CDfMLm0wHnke/QF9LTnenPmKx3E=.ed25519) [is looking for someone to discuss Scuttlebutt on their podcast](%sgw7R5/svb1DxZGe+kqyZ/dSv5fKFEBjza6kt+Stg3k=.sha256).

> I have been doing a weekly podcast since 2007 and would like to have people join us to talk about Scuttlebutt and Patchwork. It's called Visions Under Construction, and while it began as a tech talk about VoIP, it changed last year to a more human-oriented chat. We talk to people about their vision of what they'd like to see, what they're working on and how they hope to evolve.

----

[@Stephen Reid](@o2BZUubGaIcRBVb68V/5T9wE5aOMgcduDh9rEl3iYAA=.ed25519) shared [a conversation](%zDAjg8W4yhW8WIvGjMSVbrwNddwAkFKojpf7Gfwz6jE=.sha256) with [@Richard D Bartlett](@3r4+IyB5NVl2in6QOZHIu9oSrZud+NuVgl2GX3x2WG8=.ed25519) on Stephen's podcast.

## Geeky

[@noffle](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) made [an indexed-tarball creator](%QeEbj/EFoJqjneqqRinwP4ECmyEpIVmwQNEN2sBQQGo=.sha256).

> It's a tar archive, but with constant time random reads & writes & deletions, as well as ZIP-style multi-file support.

-----
[@gozala](@B/Pg4xaGbgy2CFrza9g5kGZurAILCk+NapOcTXah98I=.ed25519) shared [a list of interesting programming languages plus thoughts on them](%cAvINoHWOKU2K0kSLYIilBrJi7TIRgRZqR4NrcUrejM=.sha256).

----
[@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519) has been "...experimenting with using an oldschool relational db for scuttlebutt." Then discovered that SQLite has a JSON plugin that allows you to query stored JSON structures. Needless to say there was much geeking out over possibilities by many people.

----
[@cryptixInTheCloud](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) [shared "...a screenshot](%8gybVg06n8aw8wijMkBSbhxlFfwL2ED2DYkUqQAati4=.sha256) of tale:net and patchbay running of the scuttle-shell started by patchtron"

![tronHostedAppsVisScuttleShell.png](&nXpf18Yi1oXTSCYYv7+Si3a9EQfId3ifpVPAeJSGVYU=.sha256)

----
[@aljoscha](@zurF8X68ArfRM71dF3mKh36W0xDM8QmOnAS5bYOq8hA=.ed25519) [forked a post](%uJX/grT0vK9opXvlmf0eQB+SCrpWirZRzkrCcCxmQU8=.sha256) about a database that allows efficient querying of the causal order of ssb messages to not derail the thread.

> TLDR: Building a database that supports querying the causal order is not trivial, but possible.

Also...
>I finally wrote up the abstract bpmux interface for multiplexing, and bpmux/rel, a concrete protocol for providing this interface over a reliable, ordered, bidirectional stream. In addition to the multiplexing features provided by packet-stream, bpmux has backpressure on all payload data, allows cancellation and closing of all logical channels, and supports heartbeats for the top-level connection, all logical streams, and requests. All of these are required for building robust distributed programs.

There are [many details for the curious](%UwYCEb0LdZymBz0llz+QcqXd004x800DHiWJiYy+P80=.sha256) 

----
[@bobhugen](@iL6NzQoOLFP18pCpprkbY80DMtiG4JFFtVSVUaoGsOQ=.ed25519) has been "...[collecting a bunch of related threads](%9VWASKdl78TVKP+Hn0bVqji6Avg0DpfSP4aUIT6rwJE=.sha256) about rethinking details of the SSB protocol."

----
----

These summaries are brought to you by [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519). I would love to hear your suggestions about how to make them better, or ideas on things to include.

If you're interested in helping out, there's lots of interesting problems to solve, and I could use help

[@frankiebee](@plo0t5t1G3h4Y+Zaxw2q5NNE+SsensLDx0TbcYhj8WY=.ed25519) introduced themselves [and proceeded to get all kinds of geeky](%ud0+C/oB6R9aC2SC3w/3ssHLhV8bD1gbA+8dt0CJoQc=.sha256) with the SSB chess data.

----
[@neftaly](@bL2vcN63d2dt16q8Z6vhZWRtzH1DKlfGOW3VlvY7knc=.ed25519) shared a tale of "heroic effort"

> A few days after the diesel-water incident, my engine seized. Despite my efforts to run diesel back through the engine, enough water remained to sit inside a cylinder and rust the piston in place.
>
> It was completely stuck - I even broke the starter handle trying to turn it over.

eventually... the little boat was able to motor again.

content.text:
## Software
[@cft](@AiBJDta+4boyh2USNGwIagH/wKjeruTcDX2Aj1r/haM=.ed25519) shared [a sneak preview of "SSB drive"](%I4DuXYTI7hBG0tJKz1IGG/uFTW/FCK5l+/Qk2HjvTsA=.sha256) 

> a new SSB implementation in Python featuring "drives" (think serverless FTP, Dropbox or G Drive)

## Software Community Intersection
[@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) shared [their experiences exploring Tale:net](%rDEmpOn6a92EB25woMEuiw+um0FPv90LspgCMTMdGpA=.sha256) I have to say the idea is fascinating, and it'll be wonderful if it catches on.  You can find more about Tale:net at <https://t4l3.net>

## Community
[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) was subpoenaed and we ended up with [a thread about the importance of showing up and being a witness](%isea7b/RFz16tCmhhMiyfQJrIUSQcdOhqDWHa75lsf0=.sha256).


## Geeky

[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) got curious and started "...to actually measure [how much memory various web apps actually use.](%ienfWuK32DKeZhg95neWGShJiRXe08yX6pW7x7++BEI=.sha256)"

There's [a github repo with the results](https://github.com/dominictarr/your-web-app-is-bloated)

ALSO...
> In the interest of working towards a transitional encoding format (supports backwards compatibility with semi-cannonical json, but moves towards a strongly specified binary format, with performance advantages)
> 
> I documented the API (that I think I'll need) for my proposed binary format. 

[Details here](%HGumETo50pIjEAexqPTifsT5t6LZi4NyWdh+cu8oGWc=.sha256) 

AND....  
Talked about [project: tests for ssb implementations](%VcB0Bt+MY88A6rL3dU/4nj/Y5wx/QjA6roRNQDuGbzI=.sha256) 

> This is my idea to help get people on board working on ssb implementations.
> The main idea is to present structured tasks that guide people towards expertise regards ssb.

AND...  
Put out a [proposal: privater gossip requests](%bcUPTg494srsf+lKOAdTpQaZFpW2VVkZF/4GAOrWcUM=.sha256)

> Currently, when you replicate with someone, you tell them all the feeds that you wish to replicate.  They could choose to record this information, and then look for those feeds, etc. My proposal is to prevent someone who doesn't already know that a feed exists from learning about it's existence during the replication handshake.

----

[@Aljoscha](@zurF8X68ArfRM71dF3mKh36W0xDM8QmOnAS5bYOq8hA=.ed25519) shared a [Proposal for a Simple-Validation Replication RPC](%7FGRr9OvcCZE4ubo87Ai7qxV3yp7kekEUIgRJxyRDUc=.sha256)

> When an ssb server receives a new message, it verifies its signature. The message may be sent in a different format than that used for signing, this is true for the current json encoding, and it may be true for future compressing encodings. So in order to verify a message, the server needs to know how to encode it in the correct format. In the case of json messages, this is really painful.

----

post 2 of 3

content.text:
[@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) [added an important command to git-ssb](%JxDrbgzfxGjDAOcyXnRCI24B6GFqbSK0Dq60OJYS4q8=.sha256)

> git ssb find-object <id>
> If you encounter a git error "did not receive expected object" when fetching a repo, you can use the find-object command to find a message id for the object. If that succeeds, try re-fetching the repo with environmental variable GITSSB_EXTRA_REPO_BRANCHES set to the resulting message id. If that works, with same environmental variable value set, push one or more commits to the branch. Then the repo should be fixed.

They also posted [instructions for installing git-ssb](%8PCs2u9BmWkPjvIx0D+f3K9bX0RRUXUJLHqcZYxflV0=.sha256).

----

[@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519)  is writing a 

> WIP (snarky) spec for a stripped down scuttlebutt using as much standard tech as possible."
> ...
> I'm frustrated at the difficulty and complexity of trying to implement ssb in other languages. There have been other efforts and none of them have succeeded. I'm also frustrated at the difficulty of building this on mobile.

They go on to [explain what the "boring core" of ssb is / would be](%uprLsJKHUPBrO22IhaKTM63JH7GEEbAk5Ti0fCMYF6E=.sha256) and how it can be a great place to start. 

----
[@keks](@YXkE3TikkY4GFMX3lzXUllRkNTbj5E+604AkaO1xbz8=.ed25519)  [says](%DB3DiPQjbokl3dewiQYDa/jn78ZBAuYcCZl7DP9TgTY=.sha256)

> I've started playing with transcript-based tests for go-ssb. I can now plug a transcript recorder between the muxrpc connection of two ssb test nodes and run the tests. Afterwards I can make assertions on the transcript, such as "there exists exactly one packet that calls x with arguments y and z" and require that it is in the transcript before the response shows up.

----
----

These summaries are brought to you by [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519). I would love to hear your suggestions about how to make them better, or ideas on things to include. 

post 3 of 3

## Software

[@squicc](@k9xSaKW2kc+Ko8Vx+xvFmVC5gEi/tIA2TpV6EBQ7MPw=.ed25519) annonced [the v1.7.1 release of scat](%NBDmzPA+n9/LFL9mje738tuN/bxoK+hk+KnzBEnRmxU=.sha256)

and then [announced another scuttlebutt chat client named gester](%FQuaR98jGilSBiMQDAL0z5yAE10MuGUmt8O9kB1V8is=.sha256) 

> a chat ui on top of the #scat stack, for anyone who wants to try chatting in scuttlebutt but doesn't spend a lot of time in the terminal. 
>...
> it's just a prototype right now, comments/ideas/bug reports welcome

![gester scat screenshot](&4xdlYKQl9tmDeV6UA+5pb3cZC4gjOV+8nDqIbZ2BZD4=.sha256)

## Software Community Intersection
[@adamsky](@M//21j5Y2CrQgZ0ig7kdmDG/sRhrz55pXpDbOAYUQkw=.ed25519) has been thinking about [Sustainable alternative physical info networks](%jSvPOUr4rMYV9XBT209Mmcrk2OCWxFgN/Go5Hgv3Wu4=.sha256)

> Lately I've been thinking about approaches to deploying sustainable decentralized info networks, systems that could serve as part of the physical alternative to the default centralized internet. This is all highly speculative of course, more of a braindump for now. If you have any relevant resources please share  :seedling:
> 
> Here are some requirements as I see them right now. They need to be taken into account during design.

----

[@dinosaur](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) is looking "to [sponsor development towards the next generation of the core Scuttlebutt protocol.](%zv56AbEcR1+XKcOF3E7J+HNoKrxsd+0MQ/eVPQanfb8=.sha256)"  in Rust.

----
[@andrestaltz](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519) [reached a milestone](%cYdzYS17WQtnrFur0himX3DBWVhuJGTscBJcAWUkR3o=.sha256): 

> Two internet peers were able to replicate with each other, pub-less! It works with an invite system. One peer creates a one-time invite code, the other consumes it. They discover each other through the DHT, then proceed to replicate. Next time they are online, they need to rediscover each other on the DHT, but re-using the same invite.

----

[@ev](@8Qee0I/DwI5DHSCi3p5fsl6FyLGArrnDz3ox9qZr5Qc=.ed25519) [added a feature to mvd](%O1EGM+9k2HAq/hCj4z9k8OgPplC7RS8h0yacbVg43Gk=.sha256) which allows you to see who easily someone is blocking and blocked by. 

> I believe by showing both who we are blocking and showing who is blocking us can paint a fair(er) picture of where and how the rifts between people have formed on the network over time.

----
[@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) talked about some backstory behind [The Maintenance Grants + Volunteerism](%SqysOM0rK7C9SEbk8qYvc10WxcpMLxcPTuz7hfj+slw=.sha256)

----
[@Andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) is wondering "What if we could just overlay SSB's safety net over the web's unsafe mess?" 

![andre ssb web overlay saftey net screenhsot](&j4JeEflLVVs4oJN5fZdY/Cb10jRDaQEtt24vfkPjj00=.sha256)

----

[@m3talsmith](@GOl+398b2kWeLi6+DCcU0i3AWD6vWmUtocBVYbpkpNk=.ed25519) is [dreaming of a distributed courseware platform](%1BzspwropnZ1DWop2T2YsOGDX+UpALFBCvbkpjpT5uI=.sha256). 

> I think I have my first #dat or #ssb idea. I want to make a decentralized courseware platform. I'm going to put together a proposal to have Red Hat fund it as an Open Source Initiative (I work there). the over arching goal is to put education in the people's hands, especially in areas of intense corruption and destabilization.
> 
> I'm wavering between #dat and #ssb because this has to have a mobile app. 

## Geeky
[@Aljoscha](@zurF8X68ArfRM71dF3mKh36W0xDM8QmOnAS5bYOq8hA=.ed25519) posted some thoughts on [Moving message content out of the sigchain](%QJEpN8LN1t3BrIkUQ3WoOMWRsMArbVUZCpTeBYcuqfw=.sha256).

----
[@Christain Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) built on that idea in his [post about Prototyping Blob Content](%rciFuVmIAi6WxamBNcF+EYSnJtngAbHwxxmtudsz3v4=.sha256).

> I've built the worst possible implementation, and I'd like to share it.

----

[@Matt McKegg](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) "[figured out why Patchwork is so bloated](%oj+hFcgWd+OEhzSauL7O8CWkaV3uss7fLuD7YxJmwlQ=.sha256)" and provided graphs and hope for the future.

----

[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519)  talked about "[untangling plugins, gossip, friends, replicate, ebt](%JGrXQcUUFi9aYzUlN/efBIRdupa4wgwKdr8vtnN1ELU=.sha256)"

> andrestaltz suggested some ideas regarding cleaning up the gossip/replication modules forking that thread to here (also piet), because it's already too many things being discussed. also I have some context to share



----
[@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) [shared some digging](%e4dDmORmRm4BDo6Drq1o5hyLyzMBdrcSSs98tlb4y08=.sha256) as they wrapped their head around ssb-links.

----
[@nichoth](@Hn9ye+0RgZDXvp+Km4EC36pN1/xB5ultjTxC0RZW2BM=.ed25519) is 

> [Making baby steps toward another GUI app that uses ssb](%58QhGhu8rMb+1da1sKr36u4VWbQFtaMNcVsXSsbpwOE=.sha256), running in a web browser. Eventually maybe we'll have a photo sharing tool (instagram like). I haven't been doing things for a while, but so far this has been pleasant.

----
----

These summaries are brought to you by [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519). I would love to hear your suggestions about how to make them better, or ideas on things to include.

[@dangerousbeans](@TXKFQehlyoSn8UJAIVP/k2BjFINC591MlBC2e2d24mA=.ed25519)'s boat's engine decided to only go in reverse, so [they took about the gearbox](%nznRMk+9Z3Xx3LJhTZO//HmLkMWxUwWWUcGIXZ9mnRo=.sha256) and found "two towers of stacked round things"

![two towers of stacked round things gears](&wxgiu6dit9aVGpfYUWMQ1bSCTvNoHEMW0TzMYU6ehNw=.sha256)


## Software

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) [released his Android client to the public as "Manyverse"](%f89BLtbzADRFO5FaC4ktwzyI0FjCTjKtnzJBzKW5rio=.sha256)  and given it a beautiful web site at <https://manyver.se/>

![manyverse graphic](&nhTZDrbZVDr7IUACCGx0WB8atJPvW7dAX/7eDFcuWpM=.sha256)

> This feels like the end of a long journey, but in reality it's just the beginning. The app barely has enough features to be usable. It's beta. There's so much more we can and should build. Today is simply the first day. 

It got a lot of publicity on Hacker News today, so please keep your eyes open for new people, and be ready to help them out.


----

[@ev](@8Qee0I/DwI5DHSCi3p5fsl6FyLGArrnDz3ox9qZr5Qc=.ed25519) has [added a "boost button"](%UM/aCxQoXzd/wyNK/59YWhYjisrNJJ4QbyGxG6t/tck=.sha256) to their %mvd client. It works like old-school retweets (before Twitter made it into a feature).

# Another week without summaries

My friends, I am sorry I haven't been able to bring you summaries these past two weeks. Have no fear though, they shall return. I do have some good, and bad news to share though...

## Good News
I quit my job! This is good news because I'll have more time, and mental bandwidth* to do the summaries. 

## Bad News
The latest version of Patchwork makes it impossible to scroll back a week (at least in the Extended Network view). It aways had pauses with the loading spinner, but now they take hours (literally).  Patchbay does allow me to scroll back that far (I think) but I can't wrap my head it's ordering of posts. I see five month old posts with no new replies mixed in with posts from two days ago. Even if I _could_ wrap my head around it it's still a very impractical for the task of summarizing the past week's worth of activity. That leads me to...

## Help Wanted
I need some geeky help. This job would be about 400x easier, and waaayy faster, if I had a command line tool that would give me the first post for every new thread in the past n hours / days. Raw JSON post data would be fine. I can handle piping it through other tools to extract the metadata, render the markdown,  and show me images. I just don't know how to extract the data from ssb, and nodejs is _not_ my forte.

I've got some ideas for some useful tools I can build on top of something like that, but I need help with that first step. 

Would you be willing to help with that?  If so please let me know on my [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) account or my [twitter account](https://twitter.com/masukomi).

----

\* mental bandwidth has been hard to come by because I'm suffering from pretty severe burnout (thus the quitting my job), but that's a post for another day on my [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) account.

Thanks [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) I'll give it a try. 

Hooray for finding the bug [@Matt McKegg](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) ! Thanks for looking into that.

![butt_summaries_image.jpg](&cIBYD4wh/L/Ivqb1Zyqc3uwFQJOB6Sgnlv3lITD/urY=.sha256)

## Software
[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) has been hearing the complaints about initial sync time on manyverse and has been [working to improve it](%3hli4+jOqRZ1EE6EckvVh74DIda+hRzabTfvHecxfqU=.sha256).

----
[Patchwork v3.11.0 has been released](%gsoWkvWuFLZxRC3ko9Ye7mHDKRs7cu3/85/lD7GvSyY=.sha256) with bug fixes, new language versions, and performance improvements. Since then there have been a couple patch releases.

![patchwork v3.11.0](&49S54+BlNMpyw4a5xXWCjdFS1mfyMt402nDfoI8id1s=.sha256)

The new version  introduced tags to the UI. While visually they're presented in a different manner from channels, and they're _implemented_ very differently. However, the actual usage of them is practically the same.  [This thread](%nnfjmuQptTp101U8ocvnJ0IeGRLfeqrFvJ8gFD6EqbU=.sha256) explains some of the details. 

Things you need to know: tags are public and permanent, so it's best not to use personal taxonomies like "bob_favorite" or  time bound ones like "readlater". Think about tagging posts with metadata that'd be useful to you, or a stranger years from now.

----
[@Zero](@uR5GhJwABZuZwhy9mI2hFYkTP0IMRG2LZkqpTkgcR1g=.ed25519) [shared](%BzlSg/yXkPMI8iWypAeixcqN6tkEzMd5r0Kyvo0mxU4=.sha256) 

> a [gallery] of very cool dat applications by great folks from a workshop held in Toronto

----

[@Martin](@pJsYrTaEjm5XW5Qe0W9JW2c+RpYNqJHPMZ0qGFFYXfI=.ed25519) works in the digital identity space and is pondering aloud about why "...about 99% of all "digital identity" projects out there claim to use blockchain (although most have thus far failed to actually explain to me exactly how/why they do so)" even though a single version of your "identity" info is usually irrelevant and wrong. They [share some relevant articles and ask for your thoughts](%AH6m6kT81y5w4Po59Zg3vXMctfzwVUHEJTE5dyDq7po=.sha256).

----
[@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) noted that [Patchwork now renders a single emoji, alone on a line, in a much larger size](%LAGvVzSNA/gbize/f+UeJYDEBIqWIMMDmvFZcpIY1Fk=.sha256) in case you wanted a big one.

## Software Community Intersection
[@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519) is "...really interested how social software adoption is driven... I'm really concerned about that for scuttlebutt. How do we get users who are signing up because they hear about it, connected easily to their communities."

They [look at the history of What's App and ponder what Scuttlebutt can learn from it](%0yG7U2PDvI5CopHG64tbou0ub/jYoDYwnDul6WROQJE=.sha256).


----
Some people [are wondering why images are, a little odd here in the 'verse](%GNs0DQsxcRpTMcKl4AnVnY7JIltI7gReLK9jr7wXykE=.sha256). Why you can see some, but not others, why they take a while to load sometimes. Some answers are there if you've been wondering.

----
[@noffle](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) shared a post by [@Hiure](@UiC9sF4U9m7v4c3UQ1qaRfxybogSgvxcGOLUkSw84Tw=.ed25519) about [mesh networking in Guyana](%X5uJFGs73DuvCOQETbwe9XEAfkCcWDFaN4qP0SC27f8=.sha256) 

> Earlier this year Dd hired @Hiure to investigate the possibility of getting broadband wifi from Brazil into the Wapichan village of Sholinab in the savannah region of Guyana. He did a write-up of his time there, which sounded amazing. Spoilers: mesh networking and jaguars!

----

[@andreastaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) discusses their idea of [Parametric Innovation](%ZNwpTLrITFJSe9XZSKJZ9VwMFOa9v2ROaPydOyqVmtM=.sha256)

> Sometimes you may have an Omega Project idea: it's something that's awesome through multiple aspects, solves many problems, innovates on many levels. It innovates too much, basically...
> Instead, you can practice parametric innovation: use boring, proven, popular features, then add just one interesting innovation.

There's more detail in the original post, of course.

[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) discussed [Plugins for scuttlebutt](%UyEnqEkxk2Sgl5467GRY1JyyWxYScWH+XhC9n4wsSEo=.sha256).

> ... with that all said, here is what I propose.
> 
> plugins run as child processes of sbot, and communicate over stdout.

Read the post to find out why.

----
Dominic has been [making some progress on ssb-tunnel](%IhQ26L7Q2Z21s+M9Ctj1j20BxbwT2Ay5iGMbP1hxYkw=.sha256), but there's still more work to do.

----
Dominic also [wonders about cube satellites and cell phones](%Jx/Yij3hvL6IDO9TylIKpEn9EHUpGixbUCm8sQ8fN2g=.sha256)

>is radio communication with overhead-passing-cubesat a viable idea?
> ~OR~
> can hobbists with 2020's technology build an iridium "satellite phone" (1990's technology) on a budget? 

----
and also [swarm updates](%gUUUPZiMT89Q+2apwOy6C3WwWOTz8MjOdwj6wu7suZY=.sha256)

> A swarm is a group of peers that are mutually interested in a particular resource. This is the sense used in bit-torrent, and later used in dat. If you like, you might interpret ssb as a protocol optimized for interacting with many occasionally updating swarms at a time. In our case, that's just ssb feeds. We've done a lot of work to try and make this as efficient as possible...

----
[@noffle](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) shared [how to use vim as a hex editor](%e81zcNhZc90u7VHVd9MXTNDZUOlcuoZjuvnSFHA87Mc=.sha256).

----
[@peg](@vEJe4hdnbHJl549200IytOeA3THbnP0oM+JQtS1u+8o=.ed25519) is thinking about "[Secret keys for Dat archives](%1b2LCV91CdesRMxG3S085nB1mfedUkFK5qLkRV6QipQ=.sha256)" and "[making] it easy to backup and restore keys for dat archives with dark-crystal."

----
[@alijoscha](@zurF8X68ArfRM71dF3mKh36W0xDM8QmOnAS5bYOq8hA=.ed25519) shared "[Ramblings On Variable Length Natural Numbers](%GrYD8mj3wV5s1bqknoYa+rsoeusSuT3sjPBaktTL7ps=.sha256)" 

> The binary ssb protocols will indicate a bunch of types by prefixing a certain tag. Such a tag is nothing but a natural number. We want these tags to take up little space, so we need to choose an appropriate encoding. 

----
[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) [figured out a way to block someone without anyone knowing you've blocked them](%VuR6+pn+EfUlOKVp3DHNaBXdV2NtAG1PdjAVESfi3+4=.sha256). In other words, they implemented "mute", but with no structural changes. 

They also pondered [replacing sigil links with URIs](%g3hPVPDEO1Aj/uPl0+J2NlhFB2bbFLIHlty+YuqFZ3w=.sha256).

----
[@regular](@nti4TWBH/WNZnfwEoSleF3bgagd63Z5yeEnmFIyq0KA=.ed25519) [advocates for API Stability](%40w/AclBzc7IrN/2mTSHVdbWavoskd3fKmOTEYBgRrw=.sha256).

----
----

These summaries are brought to you by [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519). I would love to hear your suggestions about how to make them better, or ideas on things to include.

# This week  in Scuttlebutt
A sample of life in the Scuttleverse.

## Content Privacy Reminder
A couple important points came out of a side discussion of last week's summary that bear repeating. New people should definitely pay attention.

1. By default the public SSB Web views do not show your content unless you opt-in, _but_ because this is a distributed system we can't enforce that.  Private messages to your friends are still encrypted, and private and can't be displayed.   As with all social networks, **you shouldn't post anything publicly that you're uncomfortable being accessible by the world at large**.
2. The convention of only showing content of people who opt-in _**does not apply to images**_ (for technical reasons).

They also "[described Manyverse with Diagrams](%exx7IUorzJ+GRDwkXzR9l3k3RPCbVkWB+t/QaWS8Wpc=.sha256)" like this one

![manyverse diagram](&ZQOZJYVypkrAE7sl6hHwnI5KJN0DnU5UnPd85Klz9fg=.sha256)

and went to a Crab Meet.
----
[rabble](@5fYRrgyJON0r0R9SPrK0oxR1XKhqNXqiN0FBX+MgfH4=.ed25519) gave us a nice [update on the development of ~Verse](%3pxgrK6q2CPjsF529SQDDpa1bopYOcd/A76qcMc3rSE=.sha256) which is / will be built on top of scuttlebutt.

![~verse Screen Shot 2018‚Äì10‚Äì22 at 6.00.57](&Epj6Qmt+ZmMmg7WvS2sQthAndZCt3ToijxRzUhPj2ZU=.sha256)

~Verse hopes to be a 

> Social / content-distribution platform able to promise no ads, less harassment, 
better privacy and inbuilt payments and content subscriptions by default.

## Community
[elavoie](@IgYpd+tCtXnlE2tYX/8rR2AGt+P8svC98WH3MdYAa8Y=.ed25519) [shares](%b9u34D9HglR6RunOUwfFOYfIC8G0975qO0TQRB1Ftrk=.sha256)  

> The Candidacy Period is drawing to a close, with a great roster of candidates. Before launching the Election/Voting period, I would like to reflect back on the representativity of the current tentative Council, based on criteria suggested by many participants, including myself. As you will see below, I think the current candidates collectively represent a wide range of viewpoints. From my personal experience, I also think they have demonstrated useful contributions in the past and have shown to be trustworthy.


----
[Daan (the other one)](@Bk5uzkFxdMJnJR+rKVd+X4LO/u+8VV+lA14e+XLabXQ=.ed25519) [makes a plea](%Jk2+sa1woKdIWyuRpWiim6luIAuuyc8oqkc05bvM9Go=.sha256) for us to "**Please** stop naming things in clever, tongue-in-cheek, butt-related ways." They go on to share some of the thinking why, which I'm sure many of us have also had. 

----

[hoz](@RtsOc2h1gqh0fRrjrUTHAkRBu9YyDgsD+EWsfLpykrc=.ed25519) [shares a info on](%9Gi4ZebmQ4po3abItzrotYKfwa0394iEZeANs9FtpTk=.sha256)

> ...a book on the survival strategies and recommendations of women in poor communities in Puerto Rico in the aftermath of last year‚Äôs hurricanes...
> ...the majority of the text is quotes from the participants responding to a series of guide questions, interspersed with some additional analysis from the authors. The quotes have heart-wrenching stories of neglect by government and despair, but also many stories of women and communities coming together, and learning how to flourish in the aftermath of the storms.


## Geeky
[cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519) theorizes that "[sameAs and private-groups could be the same thing](%mai+JnAw2DJjvlr4FRBzp+kH3w0FsclopQrs5QqaMF4=.sha256)"

> Some wild brainstorming even though another solution to #private-groups is in the works! :zap:
> 
> Feeds are limited to one device so they don‚Äôt get forked. A ‚Äúperson‚Äù is a collection of device feeds. That sounds like‚Ä¶ a private group!
> 
> If‚Ä¶ * A ‚Äúgroup‚Äù is any collection of other groups or device feeds‚Ä¶ * You can treat a ‚Äúgroup‚Äù just like a feed (send private messages to and from, follow it, block it, etc)
> 
> Then we could build arbitrarily nested groups-of-groups!

They go on to expand upon those thoughts and why it's interesting.

[@elavoie](@IgYpd+tCtXnlE2tYX/8rR2AGt+P8svC98WH3MdYAa8Y=.ed25519) notes that [The "ButtCouncil" seems to be converging on "Handshake Council"](%uUU9Ifh6ffz6Le166GaOjkPWC54rrx86aZXrFVHuYd0=.sha256) as a replacement name. 

More importantly, people are encouraged to [vote on the election of the council](%4/tik/N0UjuigPKUw3WGkK8UC/R2disgoPaKn3ijdYw=.sha256).

In [an unrelated post](%PVuWvsRgiQl8n7rrfrWEJ59lLE1a3xBN39VqTD4RCMg=.sha256) they ponder the growth of our community in the coming year, and some of the implications, including the need for clients  to support multiple identities.

How many scuttlers can you spot? 


## Geeky
[@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519) has [been making progress on querying SSB with GraphQL](%DgQy2LDK42gcvyQMZxIaZcw1w3Dxx/NNz2/ER74MfxQ=.sha256) and shows how to get started.

----

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) [spent some time analyzing the open source licenses of many popular open source programs](%7IyCfNYmr6yQnWq3RANab/0p9/cjHYrCvnYqYrftkFs=.sha256) with an eye towards how compatible, or not, they were with the Apple App Store. 

----

A recent discussion of GoTenna got [@Tulsi](@NdIxvdkjFol8q/HpP37xo1ZMi7oXMGXoqI2sw4F1JCA=.ed25519) to share a nifty open source alternative which resulted in [a discussion of its guts](%KxS3pMIONiMmHJJCS3/PPI6YJpx2tld9xe8CUKqK8jM=.sha256).

> This documents objective is to outline the process by which you may form and reliably operate a Space. A Space is an instance of the Space Protocol, and as such it is a place of interaction, collaboration, and creation, offered for the fulfillment of an intent.

> The Space Protocol enables you to reliably collaborate with other Space Agents, organizing without necessarily favoring centralized and/or hierarchical structures. (Although the protocol allows the expression and operation of legacy organizations if such is your desire).

> * database can store this instead of json

[@moid](@Sur8RwcDh6kBjub8pLZpHNWDfuuRpYVyCHrVo+TdA/4=.ed25519) shares some info about how "[The economics of wood here in New England is so wasteful](%4gOmz4IzbIAd9WMRlsjzWu77Mtv9BQwaSvt7bjnA/NE=.sha256)"

and then [designed their own circuit board](%Zp7dYcNQi1+1xiBCxVX27FQmI9dfPS5pVh2YQKXdnH8=.sha256) "LED‚Äôs display each relay‚Äôs state, but mainly added to have more blinking lights."

[@Mathijs](@OP9jTRHgk3T999VOhWNAJOBVqAoyhTaTmT5daKBqH8s=.ed25519) shared [some info about how reforestation may be our best strategy for climate change adaption / mitigation](%hG0Smq4qAENBjAkPpgmVJ8PCw0jLIcTpHCjxipVK9EA=.sha256)

![climate mitigation potential](&ySkgA8FiFIcRxwD+bu6BfIUnwTjV7wL4vu5XDDZiSTI=.sha256)



----
[@polylith](@0nakXtVIodBfdHwRQLVb64p54jTWS+DFHRqg58ky4CI=.ed25519) has been [carving things out of green wood](%x7SA3hC23wGPcJ4U5fkdUKYj4gDCTTZSKI27K0mng6c=.sha256) with simple edge tools. 

![A pile of spoons and spreaders carved from birch, cherry, and maple](&qcIRooMsrLvTf5J/iLhg+ljsWWdd6cTFXLF+6Z86xho=.sha256)

----
[@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) shared a "[Fire Light Sunrise](%aahoKm5g1Vo1Zu+zUFixPtzmtycr+vU8oOpTG/j+jaQ=.sha256)" and other interesting photos

![fire light sunrise](&U4idCFg8YEKus6Bxq+2OHc8ppasHdQF70lTDJb+1FHA=.sha256)

[@Sam Smith](@w87xXIicF6SVqG0VIBqbKfHJ/QuXdBOBhtMUweZxE4k=.ed25519) shares [an update on their Metabolizer project](%PS+8B/DK3GkdCtEwTt8faL9LJjdT5r4aRtAZGPtwbwg=.sha256).

> The prototype I‚Äôve got going is still quite basic, but it works remarkably well, all things considered. I‚Äôm able to shred and thermally decompose wood chips, amazon packaging, junk-mail, refining them into a clean syngas, storing them in a gasometer, and then use it to power natural-gas appliances and lightly-modified internal combustion engines.

They've also got it powering a cool 3D printer that uses milk bottles from a shredded powered by a generator powered by the gasometer...

![3D printed milk bottles polypropylene](&MU9cvGOQwQI/60RwA60UnbOM/YGV1xHt2yz/Poi/B6g=.sha256)

## Software
[@Alanna](@6OxffMLNyxkboLjCqv29WnMPhH8O3qFrcXCR6KrKcPI=.ed25519) shares [some information about Aether](%JzhINjBntgzAe0F/vRcA/5VVUHfMpe7gh9FgmuVIykk=.sha256). For those who don't know,  it's kind of like reddit, but p2p and ephemeral, and... well there's more in their post and on the ether site. 

----

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) shared "[Infinite Game](%7aw//w7CkOyBSV5H8iEYs2dhvV3CP4ANsvByIgrqEPI=.sha256)"

> Designed to help you find times to gather with peers, celebrate the successes so far, and look forward to a better future
> This is a standalone client which assumes you already have a scuttlebutt identity.

![infinite-game-calendar](&CohfSHVODiMjnNC5Wo/p+a2ojmqxJfFGlob7Ytybnmw=.sha256)



### Software Community Intersection
[@sam_uk](@4xqgty3pil6QW3CoO1RcuTFGRuhsTcp+jGZvA6aCSAo=.ed25519) ponders [what would happen](%E0LEibUXxMx3wzaJ+BkxpAcdaGofBHo5voYhZ21FzFQ=.sha256) if we paid to install manyver.se on 10,000 phones in Nairobi.


----
[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) has [some useful information for most of us](%yZimmIftSQLo24Ggiluz2xlunZWLMuUTLp9NqwxvX/o=.sha256)

> You may have heard of the perils of forking your feed. This post covers what a fork is in this context, how I diagnosed my fork and then how I fixed my fork

Separately they [share some info about an article](%N1h8Iw+p1LGm0a/aOZ2UBFFkTtLveC4Z0izqmF7VEF4=.sha256) titled "Shatter Secrets: Using Secret Sharing to Cross Borders with Encrypted Devices" 

> Abstract. Modern consumer electronic devices such as smartphones and laptops are laden with intimate personal data such as past conversations, photos and videos, medical information, and passwords for services that contain information on our entire lives. This makes the devices of particular interest to law enforcement officials during even routine searches. A particular threat to users is when crossing international borders, as we have repeatedly seen reports that the data on these devices is subject to search and seizure without warrants or even suspicion of wrongdoing. In some cases, travellers have even been compelled to provide PINs, passwords, encryption keys, and fingerprints to unlock their devices.

Considering how many countries have different ideas about what is "acceptable" and some require you to allow border control personnel to poke through your computer or phone this is a concept worth considering, even if the software isn't there to make it trivial yet. As someone who really likes crossing borders this is an issue I wrestle with regularly. 

---- 

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) shared some of the progress that's been happening with the SSB "mobile quests" including but not limited to an iOS proof of concept. That and more in their [Retrospective on mobile quests](%r3uOjOJj/DxIJEpsJEIBt8kzH5c47fOrGTjo+b9Hk70=.sha256)

content.text:
(continued from above)

Then they posted about [How to detect centralization creep](%sIe9BPNG+van7FtOp3q8SQPj9EirCQBqB59Jfuri2EM=.sha256) which is something our community should be on the lookout for. The decentralization of SSB and the clients is what helps keep it awesome. Then again, some centralization can make digital life a lot easier. 

### Community
[@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519) shares [a post about "what it means to be open" and working in the open](%r6+MjXcE/sNTJYIPLSDXkldaVPXBssLP6I1eM1PZAls=.sha256). They go on to pull out quotes that are relevant to us and add their thoughts.  This quote is one that made me bookmark the article for later reading.

> ‚ÄúOpenness‚Äù in this context is about accessibility and physical and emotional safety, about the ability to participate without fear. The checks and balances are principally about inclusivity, accessibility and community norms; codes of conduct and their enforcement.

----
[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) shares [info about the Gitcoin grants and a proposal](%N3Z+P0r4iTFJ91AJkCJQsco3JV9rfFl7vjj+XE3Pp88=.sha256) for how the Handshake Council might match funding. 

They also discuss [a proposal for how the council might pay itself for the time the members spend working on it](%WjuZ4N7OXS7GkrduwkNS+CYhu8BhjMDxO88OI987SJY=.sha256) and [how they should go about making decisions](%gYlJd+XG9n+FU26H74j2d2136aVCUvCX6CoidraMHXs=.sha256)

----
[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) proposes a "[Scuttle Summit](%SI/1DdkAB7cJpM/dxyi4WjEL0ZJkxXAtVB08VeY1CkM=.sha256)" 

> Let‚Äôs meet up some time soon. It would be great to share a meal with you all, to sit around a fire, to learn more about what you do in life (your odd hobbies), and to dream about the future of scuttlebutt together.
> ...How about late February 2019, in New Zealand? It‚Äôs the perfect time of year, and there are lots of people here who‚Äôd love to welcome and host you.

## SSB Beginners Corner

[@af](@UYyBSgcbRAlNxWZkuU0oCYLo2s2cV3yh4FDUv/OxVwQ=.ed25519) says 

> [i'm not sure how the relevance of someone's posts works on ssb](%WOywg46XTtNxUIcvfL4oRnqTPa0gqV1A5CF9inGbn7E=.sha256), but i feel like that if i don't directly engage with any other user and do not post on channels, very few (if at all), will get my posts on their feed.

The short answer is that the visibility of your posts is not affected in any way by how much you post, what channels you post in, or who you interact with. More details are in [the thread](%WOywg46XTtNxUIcvfL4oRnqTPa0gqV1A5CF9inGbn7E=.sha256).

## Software Community Intersection
[@peg](@vEJe4hdnbHJl549200IytOeA3THbnP0oM+JQtS1u+8o=.ed25519) started [a wishlist](%mof4xfyQRJ0rmeEaXp4VA+mcVNy0rc5q7CbAzN9ifvQ=.sha256) "...for listing features or things to do (eg: research, testing, documentation) that we would like to see in dark crystal in the next release, or within this funded period."

----
[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) notes that [@christianbundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) has brought the markdown rendering in `ssb-markdown` up to modern standards. [Details here](%CAzkG+w3Gs1uNtScaEycSumsNdosa5vbyT+r3O9c4M4=.sha256).

## Community

[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) reflects on the past year of community building here, and asks 

> How are we going with our [community] Gardening? How are we going with our increasing of boundaries, cultures and diversity (borrowing from some Permaculture notions of Boundaries as the Zones of maximising diversity where different ecosystems fuse

Let them know [here](%N9jf2vmHTFfHmw2hOWk+gnJhn07uHO7mnernIhsUYyU=.sha256).

----
[@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519) shares...

> I just got back from a couple weeks in New Zealand and Oakland for the Non-Profit Developers Summit.

> The biggest news is that #verse has secured funding to build applications and services on #scuttlebutt. Our lead investor is BloombergBeta. They‚Äôre the lead investor backing Open Collective, and have funded a number of other companies like Meetup, AngelList, and Codecademy. I talked to founders who‚Äôve worked with them I felt like they really got what scuttlebutt‚Äôs about. We also took funding from angel investors (individual wealthy people) and two other small firms Fuel Capital and Upside VC. There‚Äôs a bit more space so we might have another couple investors come on board to fill out what we‚Äôre calling a pre-seed round.

There are a lot more details including future plans for improving the verse [in their post](%1TuDOEBKtSPYj/ctsL9oEhS0Yoh3KVAJkLUBzzr1Qmo=.sha256)

----
[@enkiv2](@Q6jeOaoJOdFq8/3oFaOYC6bKhaVCD3IIdpjG+7Fab2M=.ed25519) [shared some thoughts](%PlnTpvroY9ZXtPh/VRK5qvWReHEuqaoTN9r5SlISft0=.sha256) about how "Users develop craft‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääincredibly complicated folk-ontologies, rituals, procedures, and heuristics‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfor working with whatever tools they regularly use, & this craft is itself a tool." and how that applies to making "...more flexible UIs with more programming-language-like expressive power".

----

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) started "...[building... docs which are an overview of the ssb ecosystem.](%PI81jNfHq0L3Rp0TXuTMn5jK1QKGCK1dj9tXbmUAkro=.sha256)"


## Geeky

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) notes that the `secure-scuttlebutt` JavaScript module has been renamed to `ssb-db`. Details [here](%Baxk971HDDPZGYD3cggUSq5Ts/ZD2eiseCUShi4Rf4Y=.sha256)

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519)

> ...did some pairing with [@matt](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) yesterday and we extracted an about-cache out of his recent patchwork refactor and moved it upstream into the ssb-about plugin. This is a major change to that plugin, and removes its index (it now uses just ssb-backlinks directly and is super efficient).

[@jfr](@e84qV/tx9w1ZiOIxU3+fOpirrT8rP3YqDydRgfk076c=.ed25519) has been building on [@dinosaur's](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) dockerfile and [managed to set up a pub](%9qlhTnc+zseWPF4r79aIPdfiCEu4hCjvXprRGf0Uj+s=.sha256) with a custom config on a docker container in digital ocean that shares its identity over http.

----
[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) [shares details about Shamir's Secret Sharing](%Zi83P95k/ucnlOosV+mRWIionFi/PTlUBZIYzD13WZY=.sha256)

> A bit of an update from ‚ÄòDark Crystal‚Äô. We are continuing to develop our identity recovery system, working on ‚Äòforwarding‚Äô shares to people other than the author of the secret. Parallel to this we are currently researching two areas. Adopting secp256k1 keys, and security issues/vulnerabilities with Shamir‚Äôs secret sharing and how to approach them. This article is about the latter... We hope that this will be useful for other projects considering using Shamir‚Äôs scheme for identity recovery.

# Recent Days  in Scuttlebutt
A sample of life in the Scuttleverse.

## Totally Random
[@frankiebee](@plo0t5t1G3h4Y+Zaxw2q5NNE+SsensLDx0TbcYhj8WY=.ed25519) shares friends, food, mountainous car breakdowns, knitted bear onesies, and more in [this thread from Hawaii](%geIELd2mHZc7TvOwGihFQJozAsTs3sqBwYY+EW8vNxg=.sha256). 

![friends food hawaii](&P9grVwDFNZEFWCC/Rw52oA/HiHRrVdEzJY1LaGC87gI=.sha256) 

![overheating nissan mountain car](&BzfrGpubv0vwawd9VuAB06/v667gAzmcz5IfT6lNd50=.sha256)

----
[@ColinSelf](@T1e88Mn/lFFOmDdoxsALBY1NST52+y56AWXXJIzlgd4=.ed25519) shares [some history about the Wandervogel](%JPvC0Wz+wr/GxH46r3SdS1ZMXU9jws9+ndeTzr6Oz1M=.sha256) movement.

> The name can be translated as rambling, hiking or wandering bird (differing in meaning from ‚ÄúZugvogel‚Äù or migratory bird) and the ethos is to shake off the restrictions of society and get back to nature and freedom. 

![ges ku aufmacher Wandervogel](&xLvVdHNtOKZaJ5OXUfL3bzxaawxNNeC7CT+mWEzXkD8=.sha256)

----
[@swapnil](@+mElIsb1AodRP1ytgHqtxGHbIzinOCBMHGWAhudCOCM=.ed25519) shared [some serene beauty](file:///Users/masukomi/workspace/scuttlebutt/summarizing/%OFiG8u8F1qanaNmESs+VRcN05Ux3G0Bgnr4fn/Gi3lc=.sha256) 

![sunset over mountains and water](&8oP//Zmm6FFthF6cn+QC4k4nyL4jDT6WPtv8dmgIfG4=.sha256)


# Software and You

[@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519) has been posting a series of posts laying out negative usage scenarios and how we might deal with them. Definitely worth chiming in: 

* [revenge porn](%wmb5ywd5dFRSRfj4V9dHAOpP7cS2aRCLBeji/Z5XvXI=.sha256)
* [child porn](%UADLZmssbsuviyNN+qI6HH9ddxpu5iX1aRwHS3pVt4E=.sha256)
* [spam](%4LkrAldgkvFb7XV+EqsqYrkCGQlMFLrSKjzFgrBPGSw=.sha256)
* [identity fraud](%lzIFq2qLXAJOifv4VjykW4sigpdXHFZb82JYjpcEmFM=.sha256)
* [a user's profile being bombarded with harrasment / abuse](%DZOKCalhoRf+g0rRNF/rSpEw8+xwv8fFhIVqrq5n1fM=.sha256)
* [hate speech, holocaust denial, etc](%Ok75z1HZ2q3yy7YFZ/PInbAOdeO65LUPBVIK1VlhIYk=.sha256)

It's incredibly important for us to come up with, and implement, plans for these scenarios _before_ they're a problem. They've put out some other related posts that you should probably check out too.  These are hard problems to solve well, and your brainpower will be useful in addressing them.

Here's [their overview post](%6Sp9BVDgbFyf6WB5hZr0GH19ZkNwGxTaxYQLfzc9wqM=.sha256).
 
----
[@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) is [thinking aloud about how to better handle threads in patchbay's UI](%iietnaHpffBuPwLjGj+SnmQ46R6TaipBRkgxHsyEDQA=.sha256)

![tangle-thread.png](&evS4qpaFeJptGlp7WdjzUL5Svug2vRKVPbg4y/5qrTA=.sha256

 It's a much harder problem than most people realize, and there's no way to solve it without compromises.  If you care about how threads are handled in our client you should probably read this and chime in.
 
----
**Editor's note regarding Dark Crystal:**  
I've mostly been avoiding the discussions of Dark Crystal here. The conversations about it are pretty constant and I suspect that the people who care about this stage of its creation are already involved in, or at least watching those conversations. Maybe I'm wrong though. Would you like to see updates on the ongoing Dark Crystal stuff here? Let [me](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) know. 

Side note: a decent [quick overview of Dark Crystal can be found here](https://darkcrystal.pw/?) if you're not familiar with it.

----
[@CatsCradle](@+MBwLZXAYcbRmflXGkGXPhdvKWExjwKSZDm8DuyZnTU=.ed25519) posts about [creating a workplace of lifelong learners](%8b9oXUyQ9JDLPqURFm3yzREh3iXIEMZKkvmBrubsAsw=.sha256)
 
# Geeky
[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) is working towards a [fast enough database](%7v9fH3Hz+u3RuH4X5FR2Qu4cj0VHC59ZwxokOSrCM6A=.sha256)   

> This weekend I put a bunch of bits I have been tinkering with together. It‚Äôs enough to demonstrate that we can make the scuttlebutt database significantly faster if we stop doing stupid things, like using JSON.


# -----------------------------------

These summaries are brought to you by [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519). I would love to hear your suggestions about how to make them better, or ideas on things to include.

## Beginner's Corner
[@katerino](@RJMqA+29sfOXHcFm2EIF85cGBlvx/L+Zbr20EZye5BA=.ed25519) said 
> Okay, I‚Äôm confused? The Milliways page says we‚Äôre friends, which I guess means I‚Äôm connected? But my ‚ÄúConnected Pubs‚Äù listing shows two gibberish items, neither of which I‚Äôm friends with and neither of which is Milliways? One of the two seems to be a pub I tried out a while ago before Milliways existed, but I‚Äôm pretty sure I disconnected with them? And the other is a mystery. What do?

A lot of people wonder why pubs they've never heard of show up in their list of connected pubs in Patchwork.  The simplified explanation has two parts. 

The first is that your client hears about other pubs as it goes out and tries to get (and give) recent info. It will connect to any pub it hears of along the way of and try and get updated feeds from the people you follow.  Those pubs aren't following you unless you've used an invite code with them.  

The second is that when you stop following a pub it doesn't stop the pub from following you. You need to block the pub if you really want it to stop replicating your info.  However, it's my personal belief that you generally don't want to do this, because the more pubs are replicating your content the more likely it is that you'll be within 2 hops of new people on the network. This isn't a very scalable solution for the network (or the pubs) because it leads to everybody replicating everything, but while we're still relatively small it's the most logical solution to multiple related "can't see" problems. It's on the TODO list to improve the scalability of pubs and the network.

## Software
[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) notes that [@peg](@vEJe4hdnbHJl549200IytOeA3THbnP0oM+JQtS1u+8o=.ed25519) [gave a lightning talk](%MoElms3qM5p0Lkq9x47nKsPA7GPPMooc38Nja/a1SoY=.sha256) about [Dark Crystal](http://darkcrystal.pw) at Devcon4. [Video and slides here](https://slideslive.com/38911795/dark-crystal-secure-scuttlebutt)

![peg dark-crystil lightning talk devcon4](&UaJgXyhLV2Zj98xIHBYmppVyQMX5SQyrywodMymezwI=.sha256)



## Community
[@Taeyoon Choi](@W1o0EvTFWz6rOxHl0QYuhWnCYpJ3/lnm1ZuSgUy2kQo=.ed25519) is co-organizing [an event in New York City on Saturday, December 15, 2018](%psvLHni9qBca+RPdjaQt2nmov1K/0lwlGYknDM9jppk=.sha256)

> Code Ecologies is an open forum to explore the environmental impact of computation. This public event is organized by a group of faculty and alumni from the School for Poetic Computation who are passionate about environmental justice. Through presentations and discussions, we will explore the negative influence of computational technologies and network infrastructure on the natural environment, and the precarious conditions they create for the habitat we share among various species.

 > There will be live-stream and ways of remote participation. 
 
 ----
 [@pes](@V4TpbIbKGFz5cgvJc7iD2W1aaEG/09w7xsvwLMLMNDM=.ed25519) [shared a link to a project](%qnuNd1aVK5fEs29nqYP9TSScPcGwP1uxA7ScpRG2nmc=.sha256) creating "A collection of [educational] gifs for women and non-binary people to nail tech apps, gadgets and habits." 
 
 They advise about using safe passwords, safe ways to share sexual photos of yourself, and things like that.
 
----
[@Richard D. Bartlett](@3r4+IyB5NVl2in6QOZHIu9oSrZud+NuVgl2GX3x2WG8=.ed25519) is looking for some help. About a week ago they [posted about Courage Before Hope a Proposal to Weave Emotional and Economic Microsolidatity](%82qwRa0FRZOHjCfFQPuDxwJ3Y2gs/jE5ytVpmp0HKuI=.sha256) which has garnered some attention.

They've gathered various information about what microsolidarity is and resources on how to do it, but find themselves over their head in trying to set up a DAT site for it and is looking for someone a little more familiar with DAT to help them out.  ["Can you help..." post here](%+kjfczqLyIHGWdistgAY6dASAx+5R5j9IW3/uCpMino=.sha256).
 
 
## Geeky
[@Matt McKegg](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) was part of [a discussion about improving the initial onboarding experience](%2KCpZB0jFipCKaQF8xhFqqJuazz4EGbco4grYTZq0LI=.sha256) and ended up making a pull request to support accessing indexes before they have finished.

Afterwards they went on to propose [an SSB Holding Tank :fish:](%9jJUwSknOV7vzPcpTAUbwTcDtvb5djsZ1BrvLIlstTw=.sha256)

> Following on from my recent onboarding post, here‚Äôs an idea about how to improve the horror that is INITIAL SYNC :ghost: :ghost: :ghost:

----
[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) shared [their thoughts on "why flume?"](%pYmFr6d0QwLP+YG0VNoo75PP7eYNZ1Y8C2MC9IjF5aw=.sha256) and not just a key value store or something else.

----
[@SandyG](@+McycRyGFiTqEL/mBlu0/RkdBOebqdOFySqCOEjwKx0=.ed25519) [ran out of disk space on their pub server](%Lr/uqd6CKR2g5UiDXsTwABL6bzqJud3xnuGb464NqX8=.sha256) and was provided a handy script for managing that, that was then iterated on in the thread.

[@regular](@nti4TWBH/WNZnfwEoSleF3bgagd63Z5yeEnmFIyq0KA=.ed25519) has posted _a bunch_ of updates about their work on ssb-photos and mutable messages. Just look for the (#)ssb-photos channel for details. 

In one post they describe how "tre" (their name for the app) keeps wanting to be an IDE. Here's an example of that from [this post](%+nviJDPCeH7NE4d0V8lPzW+IkJKVCBNmYN7VmK8JuvQ=.sha256), and there's another in [this post](%8uhAvJEHsgs3eRnYxLNqvkB1DwfsalKrjWOF3fj2NDE=.sha256).  There's just _way_ too much info about this project this week to meaningfully summarize it here.

![tre-prototypes-demo.png](&tim8CHM8qNISifJRfNs6AiSpQolS+lu1wjvvd4chgxs=.sha256)

----
[@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519) has [rewritten patchfox](%WGYKvqmsj0B78SbiF/xiYzTkVBstJ2Rt8IaKANlQuLc=.sha256). 

> I‚Äôve rewritten patchfox, I‚Äôve dumped Elm and moved back to plain old JS. I lost months trying to get Elm to work well with the schemaless nature of our JSONs but getting it to behave like I‚Äôd like was proving difficult. This is not Elms fault but my fault for being an intermediary FP person who couldn‚Äôt really architect the JSON parsing well. I‚Äôve ended up with a ton of boilerplate repetitive stuff for every single type of message. So, I dumped it moved back to JS and now Patchfox is back on track.

----
[@buoyantair](@b3ae566cmHDS8GYSHoKP8vsjRExQp5glpGRF1+dg0Sw=.ed25519) shares the [details of their new task manager Pavonine](%HdDWcLtLadIzc5Hnm1UEsEjn3kyuzqXxRsIutVZhQN4=.sha256). It has a web front end and a nodejs server backend with SQLite and GraphQL. 

----
[@enkiv2](@Q6jeOaoJOdFq8/3oFaOYC6bKhaVCD3IIdpjG+7Fab2M=.ed25519) writes about "[Tech‚Äôs Masturbatory Historiography](%S/o0drzMYLWlQvFpg5fdlef70gcjo17DADe90WNZEUA=.sha256)"

> Engelbart could do the Mother of All Demos in 1968 because that was the state of the art in available technology. It looks familiar not because it‚Äôs ahead of its time but because we stopped progressing‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand we stopped before catching up with Engelbart‚Äôs goals.

![cat staring into sink](&kmmxtmmG8+/VZebKbkW3/QoWCAZfCE1bSBPKAahCOuA=.sha256)


## Beginner's Corner
[@OxymoronSteinlausPC](@dEz5Na6AcBvAi13djP4SmWxnLIcQugJrrJcUMzFDkFo=.ed25519) says 

> I‚Äôve recently seen a public message in the manner of:
>  ‚ÄúScuttler x identifies scuttler y to be scuttler z‚Äù
> Sounds cryptic to me. What‚Äôs the message behind? Thanks.

and [an answer is provided](%3wBYm1G1sJI+iWnyFSgdgVhF3QCRzIiFRi5t/35wj7Q=.sha256). 



## Software Community Intersection

[@manni](@JSrjjJja0t6v2Lb8wQN3TPecpPMrdcOcOISsDe68dpA=.ed25519) [shared some of their PHD research on group chats](%RywKjxsRCorzAOViPcML6U9jCcmdPJ3nOV1et+AVO5Y=.sha256), their boundaries, and the effects on feelings of solidarity. It seems like the start of a very interesting discussion, and I hope we learn more.


----

[@Matt McKegg](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519)  writes about "[Why it is so hard to build SSB apps :umbrella:](%1bz0TXDuaM65KMTb8bgtrXuqD7L77baneTdoJ0EwRug=.sha256)"

> ...the great advantage to having many different apps for different things is that we don‚Äôt need to agree on what goes in apps, and that people are free to experiment with all sorts of different uses of SSB.
> ...But for this to be a reality, all of these apps must agree on a set of constraints and implement a compatible interface that allows all of them to run simultaneously and access the important data without clobbering each other.


----
[@Greg K Nicholson](@JoiN9c9+xO0jgu0gg5yflTf+L1peLTBneFHjrKbmcKo=.ed25519) says 

> We‚Äôve got an influx from Tumblr, and they will rightly expect to understand how scuttlebutt can deal with harassment and malicious content. What‚Äôs the state of play?
> I recall a discussion not so long ago about how well the scuttlebutt tech could handle a concerted attack from bad actors, and frankly my reading of the consensus was that we‚Äôre not sure we‚Äôre ready yet.

and goes on to [discuss possible solutions to improve blocking](%2ZQQJvIIfQaBePHbFDqXUf1jjFQdQkrqc7jlgBgYmBQ=.sha256) with techniques like "transitive blocking", and blocklists, which have been discussed before. A few useful things emerged in this thread.
[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) showed how to do a private block on the command line (for the geeky users out there) and [ev](@8Qee0I/DwI5DHSCi3p5fsl6FyLGArrnDz3ox9qZr5Qc=.ed25519): 

> I've just pushed a private block button to %mvd, so it is now easy to privately block and unblock people in the client that I maintain.

and later (in a separate discussion) [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) made [a PR to patchcore](https://github.com/ssbc/patchcore/pull/77) with support for a private block/follow mechanism.

content.text:
[@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) posted [concerns about the current state of SSB clients](%k8eJWwAdR/Ai2g9W63C5Ux1L55KYW3Z/qfTt42giJjA=.sha256) and what (in their opinion) is needed to bring them up to a point where we can really feel safe here, both in terms of who sees what we put out and what we see while here. There's a nice specific list of features

> I hope this will provoke some some good discussion. I really don‚Äôt think we are moving fast enough with some of these ideas. I would say all of these proposed features are pretty reasonable expectations from a social perspective but perhaps are technically difficult to implement.

----
[@Fenwick](@Q4rYvVUlbC0wdOhl0tmisTeJhTR/Y3PIu8yfXiMYXxY=.ed25519)
describes [some of the design decisions they made when creating the self-hosted-ssb client](%LHHIQFou6tiHT8VFcPGWK2SUQBhzqzAL4e2h+rsTj9g=.sha256).

Like why their timeline tab includes the extended network.

![the timeline tab](&OljUa50sHbKyF7H6woKCJMnXBnygwYuefYQwEYb2FMc=.sha256)



## Community
[@flpvsk](@RP01FOdcs/QABLmMxTGe1U9myUfSLN/5ItlXQcp7oWQ=.ed25519) is interested in "[open-sourcing the meetup](%qEYYtUcYm4E6wiNRAV/HaxVFt1pSKsW6JRWMUFOCOKE=.sha256)" and shares their plan for documenting how to organize a meetup, and communicate with the participants.

----
[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) put forth [a proposal for the scuttlebutt.nz website renewal](%dNdC7R84SSWSPLFcHpi0JRWsB5nwvkN50QZYJGAhX7Y=.sha256) and discusses the many ways our web based information is dispersed and inconsistent. 

> So my question is:
>  Do you agree we should renew the website by aggregating all our satellite websites and make it look polished and organized, funded as microprojects?

----
[@Alanna](@6OxffMLNyxkboLjCqv29WnMPhH8O3qFrcXCR6KrKcPI=.ed25519) shared their "...[talk from New Economy Network Australia‚Äôs recent conference](%lpoec4iTlrYW+wYKdgoF/0bg9WQyiUn0BV7KpfYltBc=.sha256) in Melbourne, about how leadership development works without hierarchy, and how to use power to distribute power."

## Geeky
[@dinosaur](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519), [@piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519), [@matt](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519), and [@ben](@N3vZ0+6yqQ0eEX5mDaXnKkwWKBUDXmqgB8D/ZzD1kIY=.ed25519) [met up on mumble to chat about _follower_ flumes.](%meil3xW/YT4WJ26mAsmLVHKxxh2rbtbM7pyvpA1N4v8=.sha256) The audio recording is available via dat and the notes suggest it covers a wide variety of interesting topics.

----

[@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) shared [an interesting way to watch scuttlebutt sync progress](%3/q9MQD+k5HGcaXS1F+1aU6pMW7tf9Jue1dmCY4BNbY=.sha256) for folks running xwindows.

----
[@dangerousbeans](@TXKFQehlyoSn8UJAIVP/k2BjFINC591MlBC2e2d24mA=.ed25519) opened [a PR](https://github.com/ssbc/scuttlebot/pull/594) that enables [support for namespaced flume indexes](%v3egUCB/5Gddttkb1u3EaMnOkR96L0UZLh3whSzBLWQ=.sha256) so that you can switch between apps (Patchwork, Patchbay, etc) without waiting for each one to reindex. 

----
[@Tim Schumacher](@o3eDT3n9urv1cyIWDuF+wQHBFj3I8OcE3L4Tla9RR8A=.ed25519) has been [reworking their ssb client](%fbsZkw/8+okG8rYKyyGhoeB60HsAbgKiv2hNtfVQHbE=.sha256) and shared [a video of it in action](https://oc.datenknoten.me/index.php/s/3m3DAFx5LtcmxAY).

# Recent Days  in Scuttlebutt
A sample of life in the Scuttleverse.

## Privacy Warning 
According to [this post](%m+HwtM9HlZws6alQoq6ybQio7jSu5a8V/pdnP+ASIvE=.sha256) from [@keks](@YXkE3TikkY4GFMX3lzXUllRkNTbj5E+604AkaO1xbz8=.ed25519)

> Right now, blocking does not work: If you get blocked, you will receive new messages of the feed that blocked you.
> ...telling people that the blocked one will not receive any new posts of the blocker makes security promises we can't keep at the moment. I suggest changing the UI in our clients to use the word "mute".

The blocked person's client may still hide the content from the person who blocked them, but if they're geeky they'll still have access to it. Even if blocking were working correctly, it's my personal opinion that you should still never publicly post anything you don't want untrusted people to see. There is nothing to stop your enemies from just creating new accounts that you haven't blocked yet. 

Be careful.  ‚öîÔ∏è

They also [shared their current insect hotel, and wondered how one might build their own Bee Brick](%BrNWKlkkOKeJPftcapDaEwfOuHiakETmFDuIZmI2whA=.sha256).

## How To...
[@Tim Schumacher](@o3eDT3n9urv1cyIWDuF+wQHBFj3I8OcE3L4Tla9RR8A=.ed25519)  shares [how to embed a video in SSB](%o8VUqQewi20p1Yj1wGXZ7EjB4QUh4H0TPeX56ge162U=.sha256)

> TLDR: Just prefix the description text with video, something like this: `[video:myvideo](&foobar)`

Practically that just means attach the video to your post and edit the stuff in between the square brackets.

WARNING: Videos are typically _huge_ and there is a max size on blobs (file attachments) so you can only do it if it's relatively small (< 5MB). Even then, it's generally not a good idea because, unlike YouTube videos, the videos here will actually be downloaded by others and take up space on their hard drives. Only the geekier folks here understand how to reclaim that space, and even then nobody wants to actually have to do it. In the future we'll have better management of downloaded blobs so that they don't fill up your computer, but we're not there yet. 

## Software

Maybe you're a geek with a few cycles to contribute? Even running the code on master will help if you can file bug reports.

content.text:
[@jeswin](@d2vneic0a0Y7OoRYvhXf+nCOBIV/lFQXHmOcHNr/3/I=.ed25519) has an interesting idea to bridge SSB into the "regular" web.


> The centralized internet will thrive for the foreseeable future. So for many people inside SSB, it‚Äôs important to be able to connect to people outside of it - for instance to share blog posts and for getting feedback. PeerBrick is an exploratory platform which lets SSB users create apps which can be accessed with a regular web browser.

 [Check out their post](%ZosOFWaOoVZwnI2FyUV0WOXQu8SihJWseOs7l934UFs=.sha256) for details on how it might work. 
 
 ----
 [@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) shared multiple posts about secret sharing. [First](%3X6ThyFg8ppDvaGZxvAVMtRkhkwJQkN4j1DGUywau04=.sha256), [Second](%e+m7/5wJ5ULoQgwxOqodPJTPBz+G40z72vM8MfS+vIk=.sha256), [Third](%DZXM7BN2y6a0eONuZKq1PRXOOh8//bG+hb+pBYsZ1MA=.sha256)
 
 > Secret sharing refers to a family of cryptographic techniques for securely sharing a secret among a group of people. An abitrary secret, such as a passphrase or a cryptographic key, is split into a chosen number of secret shares such that a quorum of the shares may be used to recover the secret. The size of the group and the size of the quorum are configurable, and are chosen prior to generating the secret shares.

----
[@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519) shared some [thoughts from a conversation with Andre](%a0zZIg2HxINqJykVQJAOsWqkeM9xO3CctQuioaxA42g=.sha256) about Manyverse, "Off chain message content", the SSB Protocal standards process, FlumeDB, our Social Graph, and more.

----
[@punkmonk](@EaYYQo5nAQRabB9nxAn5i2uiIZ665b90Qk2U/WHNVE8=.ed25519) ponders the idea of [using "SSB as a family historical archive" for future generations](%0feGs8ft4EYUa8RForwo5uYcUj98cs2FEqfy1+PVArI=.sha256).

## New Folks Corner
[@jer](@uf3kajfhBC2Sd3OysKB5LnBLJ5pwgBhBpXnGEGzgG6A=.ed25519) was wondering [why Patchbay lets you see when other people send a private message](%wIyBBiD9I4DsGVsOdQ17CqaK0hBEJqzCwX7y/HYaIX0=.sha256) (even if you can't read that message).  [@ev](@8Qee0I/DwI5DHSCi3p5fsl6FyLGArrnDz3ox9qZr5Qc=.ed25519) provided an answer.

I would love a view where I can see posts just from the people I directly follow, or potentially even tailor the value of n in my gossip protocol... I would also love to be able to browse separately to the topic channels I follow...

and [@arj](@6CAxOI3f+LUOVrbAl0IemqiS7ATpQvr9Mdw9LC4+Uv0=.ed25519) showed how you can create your own "filter bubble" like that in Patchbay.

content.text:
A user recently posted some adult content here which had  a number of people wanting to not only block that user, but guarantee their entire feed (and image) was scrubbed from their computer.  

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) [shared the instructions for this](%6wBVeuucxVQiaHaeEJHfXGd7WeDs0efbTfaGEAMNmPk=.sha256) a month ago but it is currently geeks-only. 

I'm hesitant to recommend the easy, and slow brute force way to clear stuff out after blocking someone, to non-geeks because it's too easy to kill your SSB identity and requires minor command line usage. 

There's some discussion of the current state of things [in this thread](%15PQVvXHTqIemYETpRZdNoPbQ4jfNtOcBZJCEgPS/Ko=.sha256) as well as a creative solution to kill the offending image on your hard drive after blocking the feed. 

[@craigo](@gslfzChyXwRD4A1iJ5a88gi0JmphVXyQeb77fXXj2mo=.ed25519) later shared a post about [how they used ssb-lists to make a "porn block list"](%g7rxRbjHh9XXZ2w+r7WbVOTC+aLa72Td68SKJfx/Eq8=.sha256)

> when you subscribe to the list, it‚Äôs represented as a low hop count (0.1, like same-as) so that the list‚Äôs follows/blocks are treated as if they are your follows/blocks, simple!

On the topic of undesirable content: My personal advice is to block liberally. Blocking someone doesn't make you mean, or indicate you're a bad person, and you're not curtailing the free speech of the people you block. Blocking just means the identity you blocked posts things you don't want to see. I have, for example, blocked people simply because they post large volumes of stuff I don't care about.

If you block someone and then "reply" to your own block message you can let your followers know why you blocked them and help them to decide if they'd like to do the same.

[@Dan Hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) started a thread asking "[Why do you block](%eG3uH7PIuWUUdsgddcGGA8CDK7++qRMNP+K2V9bFImQ=.sha256)?" about 5 months ago. It's an interesting read and shows a number of interesting uses of the block functionality including protecting the privacy of a loved one.

## Solarpunk
[@cft](@AiBJDta+4boyh2USNGwIagH/wKjeruTcDX2Aj1r/haM=.ed25519) managed to make their [wireless internet and laptop power completely off-grid](%vmWg44cyjNBFkotxcqg6+6ilKPYusqXtBwVsdryHdog=.sha256).

![mermaid diagram roadmap](&MXw3uEClR4TwtO2hClrC64qEjSB+WFeaw+mTSnEwYLg=.sha256)

![view-images-announcement.gif](&REz4YWlOwxQrWoWMP9SaucUNxevbnioaHNyrjVXPYto=.sha256)

[@buoyantair](@b3ae566cmHDS8GYSHoKP8vsjRExQp5glpGRF1+dg0Sw=.ed25519) shared [a resource](%OzPTwVqdyqEhMT+Ok+YtHBHnSwyTCC1PNLbwFErMTm4=.sha256) with "lots of privacy respecting software"

[@Zach!](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519) started [talking about Racket](%iOMGu/DXz8YyMsytJKcBTybPftieU/228+zaMLx8ga0=.sha256), which became a discussion about awesome Scheme stuff in general. 

![books SICP, Land of Lisp, Let Over Lambda](&KMdDiEO223i1syU9UKG5BOfFQfILeOCLbeVEsc9pWMU=.sha256)

This ultimately lead to [@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519)'s suggestion that 

> [We should build some toys using Racket](%Q3RLZIo81+m2mC1w3hqI0Opfg1UZ3dC9GfiGp5gwqXk=.sha256)‚Ä¶ (or Chicken, or Guile)

I can't help but agree, not because it's logically beneficial for the SSB code ecosystem, although an argument can be made for that, but because it's simply fun, and most programmers would benefit from learning a Scheme or Lisp. The creators of these languages have many lessons to teach, if we're willing to listen.

----
[@ktorn](@z8aJVHJTc6MM8FwaNE2GIS3AYYt2HYFNWQUO8/iydNw=.ed25519) shared [an example of explain shell](%5ENrpnVYcq2SnIs2Q8CDJQv98ksQloxPoVVkcwrJXLQ=.sha256) which helps explain shell common commands and their options.

content.text:
![the weekly - curated posts from the scuttleverse](&Q9wEqKM6UtKmMpI+W17MuwTSNTQpEtSnLvTFrgVI5EE=.sha256)

## Getting Serious About Curation.

As you hopefully noticed last week, I've updated the banner and name for this account to be "The Weekly". You create an amazing amount of awesome content. It's inspiring, moving, funny, touching, human, and kind. As I see it, my job is to sort through all those posts, and try to find the nuggets others will find interesting.

I see "The Weekly" as a gateway that helps people to connect, and see the things that make this community so wonderful. Unfortunately, creating these weekly summaries is no longer just a few hours of work. As the community is growing, so too is your output, and so too is my desire to have the output be worth your time. The result is that I'm _currently_ spending six to ten hours a week putting together these summaries. As we keep growing my work increases, and I'm going to have to spend additional time writing some code to help me find the "interesting" posts that come from the weekly output of 10,000+ identities. Right now it's a _lot_ of scrolling, and reading, and scrolling, and reading, crossing of fingers that I don't miss something awesome. 

 It's enjoyable to read through the posts of the folks I follow directly. It's _work_ to read through _everyone's posts_, write up references with nice links and images, organize it, split it up into small posts that'll fit into a submission, and everything else that goes into these summarizations. 
 
I'd _like_ to continue this work. I _need_ your help, if I'm going to do so. 

To that end, I've started [a Patreon account](https://www.patreon.com/the_weekly) where you can help support this work financially. With a little support I can stop worrying about the time I'm taking away from paying work. With enough support I'll be able to spend more time working on the summaries. Spending even more time reading everyone's posts, and making something that's even more worth your time. With even more support I'll be able to start creating new things entirely. 

There's one more, very important thing your support helps with. Supporting me here is a very concrete sign that the work I do is valued, and worth continuing. 

So, if you value these summaries, and you can spare a few dollars, yen, or whatever, please help me keep this going by [becoming a Patron on Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/the_weekly).  If you can't afford any money, but still want to help, you can message me  ( [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) ) to let me know about interesting things you find while surfing the Scuttleverse.

## Future Goals
This account is for _you_. I ask for your support so that I can continue creating _for you_.  Together, we can work towards even more. 

What else can I make you beyond these weekly summaries? What about a podcast? Regular interviews with interesting people from across the Scuttleverse? Maybe a very short weekly podcast updating you about updates to Scuttlebutt related software? 

What more can I do with you? 

[![become_a_patron_button.png](&ZmlG3j/8MfhRpszq8sm0Dssof7BXeM1RqLlAgKjK92I=.sha256)](https://www.patreon.com/the_weekly)

[Let's find out](https://www.patreon.com/the_weekly). ;)

# Recent Days  in Scuttlebutt
A moment for blatant self promotion: I've started [a Patreon account](https://www.patreon.com/the_weekly) to support this weekly summary work. I [posted about the thinking behind these here](%VmD9dUzlnpQwbSCDzz2crWkHISb27nun6kayTvLJJUg=.sha256). If you can help, it would be greatly appreciated. 

To those who have already signed up as supporters: **Wow.** Thank you _so much_.

And now, back to your weekly summary!

## Totally Random
[@Jim Pick (on iMac)](@ngA5tn8Kj7FGC6ceF1yq4gYXPUyVmUvAR+nDHJJoK4I=.ed25519) shared a lovely [photo of the Super Blood Wolf Moon](%KZQXZ4CnnirFiJfdqQ4iu4GQFmDSVc+lvRBduS26IBQ=.sha256)

----
[@noffle](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) took [an introductory blacksmithing](%rMQNROsJCqQm6DGutGSDaFpSR0SADuF6GmSNMiUpY4s=.sha256) class and made a bracelet. 

![a metal bracelet on noffle‚Äôs wrist, face-down](&xfqoF8bbisp7wlbDnjeGedp/RG8OwZQyslWQ7YcHAJI=.sha256)

Apparently there are free "open forge" days near them. Sounds like a wonderful way to get into the hobby.

----
[@warkruid](@ClMpM97cLGgpieYNBfVHwwljjcBVZGxb0v47FYmhllw=.ed25519) was thinking about [alternate power sources for web servers](%BjhVSk739rpqKH8dp8rV5Bgx5LK50rdHfqfyQubLR/A=.sha256),  and shared this picture of a bicycle powered sewing machine. 

![bicycle powered sewing machine](&ESJ/EoGyYhCNQzFp1tdKX76MCowenhUzlXkq0t8D67o=.sha256)

----
[@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519) went out to the tide pools and discovered [a pretty anemone](%n2lipCpaBjOerfV6zp89hh5zdomn+aJKPxKkTL9kEXA=.sha256) and other sea life.

## Software Community Intersection
[@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519) has been [writing out their ideas for "community-first applications"](%0sO+9kkkHFFtJLxTe6iC+MK8atOfzDjYBChWKwp9kcA=.sha256), how they came to be involved in them, and their vision for the near future of them.

----
[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) wants to know if you think it's "worth me pouring spare time into bringing [the polls tool] to a state that's useful" since people appear to be doing it manually. [Chime in here](%wVADcQi5JYuumfidXRcmynWZSFmoDwcMQQ+XR3r88Kk=.sha256)

An example poll: 

![example poll screenshot](&wx7YEc0Uq90nsWEBclh0OmYCvPJu0/Fxx9M3j885D4o=.sha256)


----
This one's a little bit software, a little bit geeky, and a little bit community. There have been a number of discussions about blocking lately, and [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) was [wondering what that the graph of blocked people, and groups looked like](%y6UtbUVgV9biTXWqeV35296WMNREa1yG8IWENlfpqls=.sha256).  This also involved updating the `ssb-to-graphml` tool.

![graph of outcasts and moderators](&Mnxk8aOvT85NVBVutj4rzTyfhzCtKrbuJEwAmMh/SGc=.sha256)

----
[@dan hassan](@NeB4q4Hy9IiMxs5L08oevEhivxW+/aDu/s/0SkNayi0=.ed25519) has generated a _lot_ of content this week. Most notable for this section are [logs from the Handshake Council](%/62iA4/HaiXi0HqjFUNe4z/ku4YSLvh1ZS5KD/9yBck=.sha256) and [continued updates on Dark Crystal](%QR3T8sX+NaqWDq4GxwYop9UR8a2/iemQiW+11L0AU94=.sha256).  If you're interested in Dark Crystal progress you should really be following Dan.

----
[@duncan](@Wbmkx0zKN/zFC1Li7Mz3IEQlcnHT7gAQ38i3hRCqyp4=.ed25519) spent some time ][explaining How DAT Works](%m6GVl09UZHb78LofCZ4qnrBPLuhrN84wMRMbuIml+Qs=.sha256), for those of you who, like me, think DAT is cool but don't really know how it does its magic.

----
Tonga lost its internet connection this week. [I](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) figured that [this is an amazing opportunity to introduce a Scuttlebutt to folks who could really use it](%BE4CX7L2+bRmI8vZdX90lGpr9MML0MtNVq1R3nvx0Oo=.sha256). Once they've got their net back, they'll still be pretty motivated to have a social network that'll survive future outages...



## Community

[@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519) shared 

> In the last (#)handshake-council meeting we had a really interesting discussion that started off with [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) asking about what is the scuttle culture. I was a bit caught off guard since I missed the last meeting, and my first thoughts were that it was about the good and non status quo content that is distributed around this community. I concluded with a question: why do we gather around the camp-fire which is SSB?

There's a bunch of interesting thinking [in the post](%fcy3MhJehNPnmfZc8CtO9Xit43Z1Nyq/0htnckGh4jo=.sha256). Including, but not limited to: diversity, vulnerability, and inclusivness.

----

## Geeky
[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) has [released `ssb-sqlvisor]` (written in Go) which sucks your feeds into a PostgreSQL database and provides a simplistic UI providing an overview. The repo contains some sample queries.

[Click through](%FeXkqUqHUW1hoyQUEdqrACCLOY+tgxbPWycB3PcNgCY=.sha256) to see the full release notes.
